children: A 64-year-old woman is hospitalized for a 2-day history of left-sided facial swelling, with associated pain and numbness, and fever and chills. Medical history is significant for newly diagnosed, untreated, poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus.
On physical examination, temperature is 39 °C (102.2 °F), blood pressure is 150/88 mmm Hg, and pulse rate is 102/min. The clinical appearance of the patient is
Large, black, necrotic lesions are located on the upper palate.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is a significant risk factor for mucormycosis.
Mucormycosis should be strongly suspected in immunocompromised persons presenting with an oral or rhinocerebral necrotic lesion.
The most likely diagnosis is mucormycosis (

) caused by genera in the order Mucorales. Mucormycosis is the third most frequent cause of invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised persons but is rarely seen in immunocompetent persons. Particularly at risk are patients with neutropenia, diabetes mellitus, and acidosis. The most common mucormycetes are

species. Infection is acute and rapidly fatal, even with early diagnosis and treatment. Major blood vessels are invaded, with ensuing ischemia, necrosis, and infarction of adjacent tissues. Mucormycosis has five major clinical forms: (1) rhinocerebral; (2) pulmonary; (3) abdominal, pelvic, gastric, gastrointestinal; (4) primary cutaneous; and (5) disseminated. The presence of oral necrotic lesions strongly indicates an invasive mucor infection in this patient. This patient has left eye proptosis, with accompanying ptosis of the upper lid, and generalized palpebral swelling and erythema, and left facial drooping. Signs of orbital infection include periorbital edema, proptosis, and blindness. Spread from the sphenoid sinuses to the adjacent cavernous sinus can result in cranial nerve palsies (cranial nerve VII in this case), sinus thrombosis, and carotid artery involvement. Definitive diagnosis frequently requires a biopsy with histopathologic examination, which is the most sensitive form of diagnosis. Treatment requires reversal of any predisposing condition, extensive surgical removal of affected tissue, and early antifungal therapy. Initial treatment is high-dose liposomal amphotericin B, with later de-escalation to posaconazole or isavuconazonium sulfate.
